Former Names: Claim Shanty, Chemistry Laboratory, Brick Building
Brief Description: A small brick structure completed in 8 days to demonstrate good faith on the part of Fort Collins to locate the land-grant college here.
Architect: A.K. Yount

Former Names: Main Building, Administration Building, College Hall, College Building
Brief Description: This 3-story, 40x60' structure welcomed the first class of 3 students in September 1879. Additions in 1889 and 1903 contributed an assembly hall, armory, and basement gymnasium. This campus landmark was destroyed by arson in 1970.
Architect: George E. King, James W. Lawrence, Montezuma W. Fuller, Willis Adams Marean

Former Names: Weaving and Ceramics Studio, Electrical Engineering, Civil Engineering, Dormitory, College Boarding Hall
Brief Description: Originally constructed as a boarding hall for students and remodeled for academic use in 1893. Doubled in size by a major addition in 1990, it provided offices for the Division of Continuing Education, the Office of Admissions, and INTO.
Architect: Hiram Pierce

Former Names: Printing and Publications, Foods Research Laboratory, Student Health Service, Veterinary Medicine, Library, Commercial Building, Chemical Laboratory, Barn
Brief Description: Initially built as a barn, it soon became a chemistry lab and later a veterinary lab before housing the college library from 1905 to 1928. In the 20th century it provided space for a variety of academic departments and college facilities.
Architect: Bryan S. LaGrange, Montezuma W. Fuller

Former Names: Industrial Science Building, Arts-Industrial Arts Building, Mechanical Engineering, Mechanic Arts Hall, Mechanics Shop
Brief Description: This red-brick building with several later additions has housed a number of departments related to mechanical engineering, industrial sciences, manufacturing technology and construction management.
Architect: James W. Lawrence, Harlan Thomas, The Austin Company

Brief Description: Converted from a horse barn to a dairy barn in 1902, this structure had two gables, and a cupola with a weather vane in the shape of a cow.
Architect: James W. Lawrence

Brief Description: The 1889 barn on Laurel Street was the first of five wooden buildings  that made up the College's first veterinary hospital.

Former Names: Veterinary Science Annex, Conservatory of Music, Domestic Science Hall, Botanical and Horticultural Laboratory
Brief Description: Originally designed as a botanical and horticultural laboratory, it was remodeled in 1895 to meet the needs of domestic science courses. In 1910 it became the Conservatory of Music.
Architect: Otto Bulow, James W. Lawrence, James Cassidy

Brief Description: Very possibly built from the bricks of the demolished Claim Shanty, this small structure was used for horticulture, and in 1978 became the forensic lab of Dr. Michael Charney.
Constructed of red sandstone on College Avenue, this was the first building to house the departments of Agronomy and Animal Husbandry.
Architect: Harlan Thomas

Brief Description: This structure that would become the first official house of the college president occupied the site of the current Student Services Building.
Architect: Harlan Thomas, F. B. Gough

Brief Description: Based on the name provided on an 1895 map, this building (on the current site of Guggenhiem Hall) was probably related to the short-lived attempt to grow cigar tobacco at CAC.
This small train depot on the east side of the railroad tracks provided a convenient station  for students near Old Main.
Architect: Montezuma W. Fuller

Former Names: Horticulture Hall, Horticultural Hall, Botanical-Horticultural Laboratory
Brief Description: Formerly located on Laurel Street just east of the railroad tracks, this structure was used for horticultural studies until 1949, when new greenhouses were build on Lake Street.
Architect: Harlan Thomas

Former Names: Speech Building, Botany Building, Chemical Building
Brief Description: Built of red sandstone from the foothills quarry at Stout, it was used for chemistry courses until a fire gutted it in 1921. Rebuilt to house the Botany Department, it later became the Old Main Annex.
Architect: Harlan Thomas, Montezuma W. Fuller, Eugene G. Groves

Former Names: Occupational Therapy Research Annex, Nutrition Research Lab, Student Health Service, College Dispensary, Entomology Lab, Lavatory
Brief Description: Built to serve as the first campus lavatory and featuring flush toilets, tubs, and showers, this red brick building  had a variety of functions before it became the Occupational Therapy Annex.
Architect: Harlan Thomas

Brief Description: A massive, two-story  structure built of heavy timbers on a thick base of native stone, the barn was located on the highest point on campus, which was leveled and is now the site of the Clark Building.
URL: Wasn't able to find the right information
Architect: Harlan Thomas

Former Names: Geology, New Electrical Engineering, Zoology-Entomology, Electrical Engineering Building, Central Heating Plant
Brief Description: Planned as a central heating plant as well as to house the Electrical Engineering Department, this was the first campus building to use light-colored sandstone. After 1906 it housed Entomology and Zoology studies and the College Museum, whose preserved animal specimens were mostly destroyed in the 1938 campus flood.
Architect: Harlan Thomas, Eugene G. Groves

Brief Description: Located at the current site of the Animal Sciences Building, it seated 250 students in two classrooms dedicated to instruction in judging livestock. It was replaced in 1959 by a new stock judging pavilion on Pitkin Street.
Architect: Harlan Thomas
